task.title: CVE-2019-18935 - Progress Telerik UI for ASP.NET AJAX - Insecure Deserialization ðŸ’°

data.title: CVE-2019-18935 - Progress Telerik UI for ASP.NET AJAX - Insecure Deserialization ðŸ’°
data.body:
### Description: 
> Progress Telerik UI for ASP.NET AJAX <= 2019.3.1023 contains a .NET deserialization caused by insecure RadAsyncUpload function, letting attackers with known encryption keys execute remote code, exploit requires known encryption keys or specific settings.

#### Severity: `Critical`

#### POC: 
- http://packetstormsecurity.com/files/159653/Telerik-UI-ASP.NET-AJAX-RadAsyncUpload-Deserialization.html
- https://github.com/bao7uo/RAU_crypto
- https://github.com/noperator/CVE-2019-18935
- https://know.bishopfox.com/research/cve-2019-18935-remote-code-execution-in-telerik-ui
- https://github.com/rapid7/metasploit-framework/blob/master/modules/exploits/windows/http/telerik_rau_deserialization.rb
- https://github.com/menashe12346/CVE-2019-18935
- https///github.com:menashe12346/CVE-2019-18935.git
- https://github.com/quyt0/CVE-2019-18935-exploit-study
- https///github.com:quyt0/CVE-2019-18935-exploit-study.git
- https///github.com:hnytgl/TelerikUI-RCE.git
- https://github.com/0xsharz/telerik-scanner-CVE-2019-18935
- https://github.com/ekkoo-z/CVE-2019-18935-bypasswaf
- https///github.com:ekkoo-z/CVE-2019-18935-bypasswaf.git
- https://vulncheck.com/xdb/c621c71a9bf3
- https://github.com/clarkvoss/telerik
- https///github.com:clarkvoss/telerik.git
- https://github.com/dust-life/CVE-2019-18935-memShell
- https://github.com/KasunPriyashan/Telerik-UI-ASP.NET-AJAX-Exploitation
- https://vulncheck.com/xdb/dffdf06b5f8a
- https://github.com/0xAgun/CVE-2019-18935-checker
- https///github.com:0xAgun/CVE-2019-18935-checker.git
- https://github.com/random-robbie/CVE-2019-18935
- https://vulncheck.com/xdb/dd4d5145d7fd
- https://github.com/appliedi/Telerik_CVE-2019-18935
- https///github.com:appliedi/Telerik_CVE-2019-18935.git
- https://vulncheck.com/xdb/8dc793fec147
- https://github.com/murataydemir/CVE-2019-18935
- https///github.com:murataydemir/CVE-2019-18935.git
- https://vulncheck.com/xdb/569e3fec38c8
- https://github.com/ThanHuuTuan/CVE_2019_18935
- https///github.com:ThanHuuTuan/CVE_2019_18935.git
- https://vulncheck.com/xdb/48d2eb3dee46
- https://github.com/ThanHuuTuan/Telerik_CVE-2019-18935
- https///github.com:ThanHuuTuan/Telerik_CVE-2019-18935.git
- https://vulncheck.com/xdb/6733f1b67fb2
- https://github.com/becrevex/Telerik_CVE-2019-18935
- https///github.com:becrevex/Telerik_CVE-2019-18935.git
- https://vulncheck.com/xdb/de3ebe4e8ea8
- https///github.com:noperator/CVE-2019-18935.git

### KEV: True

### Shodan Query: `NA`

> Acceptance Criteria: The template must include a complete POC and should not rely solely on version-based detection. Contributors are required to provide debug data(`-debug`) along with the template to help the triage team with validation or can also share a vulnerable environment like docker file. 

> Rewards will only be given once the template is fully validated by the team. Templates that are incomplete or invalid will not be accepted. Avoid adding code templates for CVEs that can be achieved using HTTP, TCP, or JavaScript. Such templates are blocked by default and wonâ€™t produce results, so we prioritize creating templates with other protocols unless exceptions are made.

You can check the FAQ for the Nuclei Templates Community Rewards Program [here](https://github.com/projectdiscovery/nuclei-templates/blob/main/Community-Rewards-FAQ.md).

task.title: CVE-2021-3007 - Laminas Project laminas-http - Insecure Deserialization ðŸ’°

data.title: CVE-2021-3007 - Laminas Project laminas-http - Insecure Deserialization ðŸ’°
data.body:
### Description: 
> Laminas Project laminas-http < 2.14.2 and Zend Framework 3.0.0 contain a deserialization vulnerability caused by __destruct method in Zend\Http\Response\Stream, letting attackers control content lead to remote code execution, exploit requires attacker-controlled serialized data.

#### Severity: `Critical`

#### POC: 
- https://github.com/Ling-Yizhou/zendframework3-/blob/main/zend%20framework3%20%E5%8F%8D%E5%BA%8F%E5%88%97%E5%8C%96%20rce.md
- https://research.checkpoint.com/2021/freakout-leveraging-newest-vulnerabilities-for-creating-a-botnet/
- https://vulncheck.com/xdb/697fc8c15292
- https://github.com/Vulnmachines/ZF3_CVE-2021-3007
- https///github.com:Vulnmachines/ZF3_CVE-2021-3007.git

### KEV: True

### Shodan Query: `NA`

> Acceptance Criteria: The template must include a complete POC and should not rely solely on version-based detection. Contributors are required to provide debug data(`-debug`) along with the template to help the triage team with validation or can also share a vulnerable environment like docker file. 

> Rewards will only be given once the template is fully validated by the team. Templates that are incomplete or invalid will not be accepted. Avoid adding code templates for CVEs that can be achieved using HTTP, TCP, or JavaScript. Such templates are blocked by default and wonâ€™t produce results, so we prioritize creating templates with other protocols unless exceptions are made.

You can check the FAQ for the Nuclei Templates Community Rewards Program [here](https://github.com/projectdiscovery/nuclei-templates/blob/main/Community-Rewards-FAQ.md).

task.title: CVE-2025-13486 - Advanced Custom Fields: Extended - Remote Code Execution ðŸ’°

data.title: CVE-2025-13486 - Advanced Custom Fields: Extended - Remote Code Execution ðŸ’°
data.body:
### Description: 
> Advanced Custom Fields: Extended WordPress plugin 0.9.0.5 through 0.9.1.1 contains a remote code execution caused by unsafe use of call_user_func_array() in prepare_form() function, letting unauthenticated attackers execute arbitrary code remotely.

#### Severity: `Critical`

#### POC: 
- https://github.com/lasthero-887/CVE-2025-13486---Poc

### KEV: True

### Shodan Query: `NA`

> Acceptance Criteria: The template must include a complete POC and should not rely solely on version-based detection. task.title: CVE-2020-14756 - Oracle Coherence - Remote Code Execution ðŸ’°

data.title: CVE-2020-14756 - Oracle Coherence - Remote Code Execution ðŸ’°
data.body:
### Description: 
> Oracle Coherence of Oracle Fusion Middleware (versions 3.7.1.0, 12.1.3.0.0, 12.2.1.3.0, 12.2.1.4.0, 14.1.1.0.0) contains a remote code execution caused by unauthenticated network access via IIOP and T3, letting attackers compromise the system, exploit requires network access.

#### Severity: `Critical`

#### POC: 
- https://github.com/somatrasss/weblogic2021
- https://vulncheck.com/xdb/d5d4e15a3fd1
- https://github.com/Y4er/CVE-2020-14756
- https///github.com:Y4er/CVE-2020-14756.git

### Shodan Query: `NA`

> Acceptance Criteria: The template must include a complete POC and should not rely solely on version-based detection. task.title: CVE-2021-21980 - vSphere Web Client - Path Traversal ðŸ’°

data.title: CVE-2021-21980 - vSphere Web Client - Path Traversal ðŸ’°
data.body:
### Description: 
> vSphere Web Client (FLEX/Flash) contains an unauthorized arbitrary file read caused by insecure file access in the web client, letting attackers with network access to port 443 on vCenter Server access sensitive information, exploit requires network access to port 443.

#### Severity: `High`

#### POC: 
- https://github.com/Osyanina/westone-CVE-2022-1388-scanner
- https://github.com/Osyanina/westone-CVE-2021-21980-scanner

data.body:
### Description: 
> Citrix ShareFile Storage Zones Controller before 5.11.20 contains a broken access control vulnerability caused by improper access restrictions, letting unauthenticated attackers remotely compromise the system, exploit requires no authentication.

#### Severity: `Critical`

- https://github.com/Osyanina/westone-CVE-2021-21980-scanner

### KEV: True

### Shodan Query: `http.title:"vmware cloud"`

> Acceptance Criteria: The template must include a complete POC and should not rely solely on version-based detection. Contributors are required to provide debug data(`-debug`) along with the template to help the triage team with validation or can also share a vulnerable environment like docker file. 

> Rewards will only be given once the template is fully validated by the team. Templates that are incomplete or invalid will not be accepted. Avoid adding code templates for CVEs that can be achieved using HTTP, TCP, or JavaScript. Such templates are blocked by default and wonâ€™t produce results, so we prioritize creating templates with other protocols unless exceptions are made.

You can check the FAQ for the Nuclei Templates Community Rewards Program [here](https://github.com/projectdiscovery/nuclei-templates/blob/main/Community-Rewards-FAQ.md).

task.title: Support EKF2_GPS_POS_* for Multiple GPS

data.title: Support EKF2_GPS_POS_* for Multiple GPS
data.body:
### Describe problem solved by the proposed feature

Currently the EKF2_GPS_POS_* params only apply to vehicle_gps when it gets used in the EKF.

### Describe your preferred solution

I propose we move these params to an offset in the GPS driver.

### Describe possible alternatives

Do we need these offsets at all?

### Additional context

_No response_

task.title: [Project Tracker] Sensor configuration display UI

data.title: [Project Tracker] Sensor configuration display UI
data.body:
## Describe problem solved by the proposed feature
Currently it is hard to figure out which sensors are connected where, with which configuration and which priority (e.g. `CAL_MAG0_PRIO`) in a single view. For example during my [boat project](https://discuss.px4.io/t/rc-speed-boat-with-px4-episode-1-using-px4-to-control-the-boat/28429#things-that-are-still-ambiguous-to-me-22) build, I wasn't sure if I needed to set the priority of magnetometer manually or not.

This is also quite related to the calibration pain addressed in the issue #19459. What can we do to improve user experience for setting up the sensors? If so, which part should be addressed and how?

What could be great (in my opinion) could be something like this in QGC (it won't be a literal text output like this, but just for giving some idea):

```
<mag-type> | <mag-orientation> | <mag-priority> | <mag-protocol?> # First mag sensor
<mag-type> | <mag-orientation> | <mag-priority> | <mag-protocol?> # One for the second mag
<baro-type> |              | <baro-priority> | <baro-protocol>
<gyro-type> | <gyro-orientation> | <gyro-priority> | <gyro-protocol>
```

But I am also not sure what others expectation / needs are, so any feedback would be appreciated!

## Describe your preferred solution
* @davids5 pointed out that transferring device tree information over to QGC could be a solution. Could you elaborate on that?
* @dagar pointed out that having a unified view in general would be good. Could you let me know if a view I suggested above is similar to what you have imagined?

task.body:
## Describe problem solved by the proposed feature
Currently it is hard to figure out which sensors are connected where, with which configuration and which priority (e.g. `CAL_MAG0_PRIO`) in a single view. For example during my [boat project](https://discuss.px4.io/t/rc-speed-boat-with-px4-episode-1-using-px4-to-control-the-boat/28429#things-that-are-still-ambiguous-to-me-22) build, I wasn't sure if I needed to set the priority of magnetometer manually or not.

This is also quite related to the calibration pain addressed in the issue #19459. What can we do to improve user experience for setting up the sensors? If so, which part should be addressed and how?

What could be great (in my opinion) could be something like this in QGC (it won't be a literal text output like this, but just for giving some idea):

```
<mag-type> | <mag-orientation> | <mag-priority> | <mag-protocol?> # First mag sensor
<mag-type> | <mag-orientation> | <mag-priority> | <mag-protocol?> # One for the second mag
<baro-type> |              | <baro-priority> | <baro-protocol>
<gyro-type> | <gyro-orientation> | <gyro-priority> | <gyro-protocol>
```

But I am also not sure what others expectation / needs are, so any feedback would be appreciated!

## Describe your preferred solution
* @davids5 pointed out that transferring device tree information over to QGC could be a solution. Could you elaborate on that?
* @dagar pointed out that having a unified view in general would be good. Could you let me know if a view I suggested above is similar to what you have imagined?

data.body:
In https://kicad-component.tscircuit.com / https://github.com/tscircuit/kicad-component-converter

We need to load the kicad_mod file and produce `<courtyardrect />` elements

- [ ] Find a kicad_mod file to test with that has a courtyard defined
- [ ] Make sure courtyards are drawn in circuit-to-svg
- [ ] Modify kicad-component-converter
- [ ] Modify circuit-json-to-tscircuit


/bounty $75

task.title: Proposal: Add SparkFun MicroMod STM32 Processor (STM32F405)

data.title: Proposal: Add SparkFun MicroMod STM32 Processor (STM32F405)
data.body:
Title
Proposal: Add SparkFun MicroMod STM32 Processor (STM32F405)

Body
Hi TSCircuit team! Iâ€™d like to propose adding the SparkFun MicroMod STM32 Processor to the funboards catalog.

- Board: SparkFun MicroMod STM32 Processor (STM32F405RGT6)
- Product page: https://www.sparkfun.com/products/21326
- Hardware repo: https://github.com/sparkfun/MicroMod_STM32_Processor
- Hookup guide: https://learn.sparkfun.com/tutorials/micromod-stm32-processor-hookup-guide
- Schematic (PDF): https://cdn.sparkfun.com/assets/8/a/a/7/3/MicroMod_STM32_Processor.pdf

Why this board
- Expands MicroMod coverage (M.2 â€œE-classâ€ 22mm edge) and brings STM32F4 (Cortex-M4) into the catalog.
- Reusable mapping: once the MicroMod edge connector + STM32F405 pins are modeled, other MicroMod processors benefit.
- Complexity: moderate/advanced (MCU, HSE/LSE clocks, boot/reset gating, SPI flash, SDIO, USB, SWD). Seems like a mid-tier bounty candidate.

Duplication check
- I checked the public boards list in `tscircuit/sparkfun-boards/boards/` and did not find this board at time of filing.
- Also glanced at the org project board (https://github.com/orgs/tscircuit/projects/6) and didnâ€™t see it in progress. Please correct me if I missed it.

Planned implementation (TSX; no XY tooling)
- Schematic (TSX):
  - `STM32F405RG` (LQFP-64) with VDDx/VDDA/VSSA, `VCAP1/2` decoupling, `PH0/PH1` 12MHz HSE, `PC14/PC15` 32.768kHz LSE.
  - SPI flash W25Qxx (WSON-8 6x5) on SPI1 (PA5/PA6/PA7) + `PC4` CS#; HOLD#/WP# as per schematic.
  - MicroMod edge symbol with named pins: 3.3V, GNDs, `USB_DÂ±`, `USB_VIN`, `RTC_3V`, `3.3V_EN`, `!RESET!`, `!BOOT!`, SWDIO/SWCLK, SDIO, SPI, I2C, UART, BUS/GPIO.
  - Boot/reset: `BOOT0` gating via Pâ€‘MOSFET (DMG2305UXâ€‘7), RC on `NRST`, `PB2` (BOOT1) strapped.
- PCB (TSX):
  - 22mm MicroMod card outline with chamfer; custom edge pad footprint (pads 1â€“75) per MicroMod spec.
  - Place LQFPâ€‘64, crystals (3225/3215), WSONâ€‘8 flash, decoupling; indicative routing for visuals.
- Artifacts: snapshots/renders via `tsci snapshot`.

Acceptance/questions
- Can you confirm itâ€™s green to proceed and eligible for a bounty? If so, please attach a bounty and assign.
- Any preference for edge connector footprint naming or a canonical MicroMod footprint I should reuse?
- Any constraints (e.g., minimum visual fidelity for the edge connector, keepout notches, silk expectations)?
- Any components/modules to avoid for funboards? (Iâ€™ve avoided relying on XY import.)

Estimated effort
- 1â€“2 days for faithful schematic + functional PCB visualization (including custom edge footprint) and snapshots.

Thanks! Happy to adapt to preferred structure or scope.

Thanks! Happy to adapt to preferred structure or scope.
